**G.L. c. 212, \u00a73**..proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds $25,000 exclusive of interest and costs, giving this Court jurisdiction pursuant to **G.L. c. 212, §3**.

**G.L. c. 223, \u00a71**.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under **G.L. c. 223, §1**, because the Defendant conducts business in Middlesex County and the events giving rise to this complaint occurred within this jurisdiction.

See **Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, an owner or occupier of land owes a **duty of reasonable care** to all lawful visitors to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition.
See **Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the leading Massachusetts case abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and imposing a single standard of reasonable care toward all lawful visitors. Although the provided text is only a concurring passage and focuses on concerns about treatment of trespassers, the case as a whole clearly holds that an owner or occupier must exercise reasonable care to keep the premises reasonably safe for all lawful visitors. Thus the citation accurately supports the stated proposition under Massachusetts law.
See **Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693.relevant_excerpt: In Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973), the court stated that it was abolishing the common‑law distinction between invitees and licensees and held that a landowner or occupier owes to all lawful visitors a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition. (Paraphrased from the main opinion at 363 Mass. at 707, where the court adopts a general duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors.)

See **Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.**, 45.proposition: Defendant had an affirmative duty to remedy or warn against hazards it **knew or should have known** about through reasonable inspection.
See **Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.**, 45.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly adopts the general premises‑liability rule that a property owner owes lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care to protect against dangerous conditions the owner knows or reasonably should know about. It equates snow-and-ice hazards with other hazards (like a banana peel or rusted railing) and cites Restatement § 343, which is framed in terms of dangers the owner knows or should discover by reasonable care. Thus, Papadopoulos squarely supports the proposition that a defendant has an affirmative duty to remedy or warn of hazards it knew or should have known about through reasonable inspection.
See **Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.**, 45.relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances….’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice, or rust on a railing, or a discarded banana peel, the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger. See … Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 (1965).”

**Rossley v. S.S. Kresge Co.**, 339 Mass.proposition: Defendant had an affirmative duty to remedy or warn against hazards it **knew or should have known** about through reasonable inspection.
**Rossley v. S.S. Kresge Co.**, 339 Mass.case_name: Rossley v. S. S. Kresge Co.
**Rossley v. S.S. Kresge Co.**, 339 Mass.support_reasoning: The court expressly states the duty owed by the store to a business invitee as one of using reasonable care to keep the premises safe or at least warn of dangers that were either known or should have been known to the defendant in the exercise of reasonable care. It then applies this standard by analyzing whether the hazard (sweepings and stone) had been present long enough that it should have been discovered and removed. This directly matches the proposition that the defendant had an affirmative duty to remedy or warn against hazards it knew or should have known about through reasonable inspection.
**Rossley v. S.S. Kresge Co.**, 339 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The duty which the defendant owed to the plaintiff was to use reasonable care to keep in a safe condition that part of the premises to which she was invited or at least to warn her of dangers not known to her or obvious to a person of ordinary intelligence, which were either known or should have been known to the defendant in the exercise of reasonable care. … [T]he jury were warranted in drawing an inference… that the accumulation and the stone had been on the stairway long enough to have been discovered and removed before the accident.”

See **Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth..raw_text: See **Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.**, 363 Mass. 165 (1973) (knowledge of dangerous condition imposes duty to act).
See **Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth..proposition: Defendant’s employee admitted **actual knowledge** of the dangerous condition yet chose to delay corrective action, constituting a breach of that duty.
See **Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth..case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
See **Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth..support_reasoning: The opinion discusses premises liability and the duty of a business owner to keep premises reasonably safe, including situations where the defendant or its servants had actual knowledge of a foreign substance. However, in this case there is no evidence or discussion of any MBTA employee having actual knowledge of the dangerous condition and then delaying corrective action. The decision instead turns on whether the circumstantial evidence was sufficient to prove the substance had been present long enough to impute constructive notice, and the court ultimately finds the evidence insufficient and orders judgment for the defendant.
See **Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth..relevant_excerpt: “Where a foreign substance on a floor or stairway causes the business visitor to fall and sustain injuries, he may prove the negligence of the defendant by proof that the defendant or his servant caused the substance to be there, or he may show that the defendant or his servants had actual knowledge of the existence of the foreign substance. … In the more usual case, however, the plaintiff attempts to establish the defendant’s negligence by showing that the foreign substance was present … for such a length of time that the defendant should have known about it.”

See **Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.raw_text: See **Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.**, 343 Mass. 263 (1961).
See **Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.proposition: Even absent admitted knowledge, the existence of clear cart tracks demonstrates that the spill persisted long enough that Defendant **constructively knew or should have known** of its presence.
See **Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
See **Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.support_reasoning: The opinion rejects rather than adopts the idea that surrounding circumstances (like the condition of the spill area) alone showed the spill existed long enough for constructive notice. The court holds there was no evidence about how long the oil had been on the floor and emphasizes that size/extent of the oil patch is not enough to infer duration or constructive knowledge. Thus, the case undercuts the claimed proposition instead of supporting it.
See **Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.relevant_excerpt: “There was no direct evidence here as to when the bottle of pine oil was broken. The record discloses no description of the appearance of the oil which would in any way suggest that it had been on the floor for a sufficient length of time to have been discovered… The size of the ‘large blotch’ is not decisive for the oil could have covered an area so described within a few seconds or a few minutes.”

See **Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarket.raw_text: See **Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.**, 448 Mass. 780 (2007).
See **Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarket.proposition: Defendant’s failure to clean or cordon off the spill or post visible warnings constituted **unreasonable conduct** endangering foreseeable customers.
See **Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarket.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
See **Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarket.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that, under the mode-of-operation approach, a store owner is liable where it can reasonably foresee a dangerous condition from its self-service operations and "failed to take adequate steps to forestall resulting injuries." That is exactly the type of unreasonable conduct alleged in the proposition—failing to clean, cordon off, or warn of a spill that endangers foreseeable customers. The court emphasizes that the trier of fact must decide whether an ordinarily prudent person would have taken additional steps (such as cleaning or warning) to prevent such accidents.
See **Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarket.relevant_excerpt: Additionally, a store owner will be liable to a plaintiff injured as a result of a dangerous condition caused by a third party only if the owner could reasonably foresee that the dangerous condition could occur, resulting from the owner’s chosen mode of operation, and the owner took inadequate steps to forestall resulting injuries. … it then becomes the task of the trier of fact to determine whether the owner could reasonably foresee or anticipate that the dangerous condition regularly occurs and whether the owner took all necessary reasonable precautions commensurate with the risks inherent in a self-service method of operation to protect individuals from such foreseeable risks.

See **Young v. Food Fair, Inc.**, 337 Ma.raw_text: See **Young v. Food Fair, Inc.**, 337 Mass. 323 (1958).
See **Young v. Food Fair, Inc.**, 337 Ma.proposition: Plaintiff, a business invitee, was entitled to assume that the premises were maintained in a safe condition.
See **Young v. Food Fair, Inc.**, 337 Ma.support_reasoning: The court expressly states the duty owed by a store to its invitees as an obligation to use due care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of dangers not likely to be known to patrons. While the opinion does not literally say that the plaintiff was "entitled to assume" safety, that formulation is a standard way of describing the invitee’s rights correlative to the store’s duty to maintain safe premises. Thus the case provides direct authority for the underlying principle that business invitees may expect the premises to be reasonably safe.
See **Young v. Food Fair, Inc.**, 337 Ma.relevant_excerpt: The duty of the defendant to its invitees is that it is "bound to use due care to keep that portion of the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, and to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use by reason of a condition of the premises, which were not likely to be known to its patrons and of which the defendant knew or ought to have known."

See **Jolicoeur v. Dudley Sav. Bank**, 3.raw_text: See **Jolicoeur v. Dudley Sav. Bank**, 384 Mass. 32 (1981).
See **Jolicoeur v. Dudley Sav. Bank**, 3.proposition: Defendant’s negligence directly and proximately caused Plaintiff’s injuries, pain, suffering, medical expenses, and lost wages.
See **Jolicoeur v. Dudley Sav. Bank**, 3.support_reasoning: The case is an equity/probate action about setting aside a deed for undue influence, not a tort action for negligence causing personal injuries, pain and suffering, medical expenses, or lost wages. The opinion addresses whether the deed was procured by undue influence and whether a confidential or fiduciary relationship existed, and it ultimately upholds the validity of the deed, without discussing negligence, causation, or damages of the type described in the proposition. Therefore it does not provide authority for the claimed negligence proposition.
See **Jolicoeur v. Dudley Sav. Bank**, 3.relevant_excerpt: "We agree with the conclusions of the Appeals Court, based on ample citation of authority unnecessary to repeat, that (1) the deed was valid unless it was procured by fraud or undue influence and (2) the plaintiff's advanced age (in light of her soundness of mind) and her lack of legal representation did not alone make out a case of undue influence. There was no evidence that the defendants exercised any influence over the plaintiff. She initiated the conveyance and selected the price."

See **Payton v. Abbott Labs**, 386 Mass..proposition: As a result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff suffered significant **physical pain, emotional distress, and economic harm**, for which compensation is warranted under Massachusetts law.
See **Payton v. Abbott Labs**, 386 Mass..support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that, due to a defendant’s negligence, a plaintiff’s physical pain, emotional distress, and economic harm are compensable under Massachusetts law. Payton v. Abbott Labs primarily holds that Massachusetts does not allow recovery for negligently inflicted emotional distress absent physical harm, and it addresses DES-related prenatal injuries and complex causation and liability theories. It does not stand for a general rule that physical, emotional, and economic harms from negligence are compensable; rather, it restricts emotional-distress recovery in negligence and deals with specialized DES issues, so it is not good authority for the broad compensability proposition cited.
See **Payton v. Abbott Labs**, 386 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that when recovery is sought for negligent, rather than intentional or reckless, infliction of emotional distress, evidence must be introduced that the plaintiff has suffered physical harm. … In summary, we hold that a plaintiff in order to recover for negligently inflicted emotional distress must prove the following: (1) negligence; (2) emotional distress; (3) causation; (4) physical harm manifested by objective symptomatology; and (5) that a reasonable person would have suffered emotional distress under the circumstances of the case.”

See **G.L. c. 231, \u00a785**..proposition: Plaintiff’s conduct was at all times reasonable and prudent under the circumstances, and she bears no comparative negligence.

See **Mass. Gen. Laws c. 231, \u00a76B**.raw_text: See **Mass. Gen. Laws c. 231, §6B** (interest on damages).
See **Mass. Gen. Laws c. 231, \u00a76B**.proposition: Plaintiff continues to experience intermittent hip pain and limited mobility, entitling her to **compensatory damages** for pain and suffering.
